channel.title: BBC News - UK Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Foreign secretary Dominic Raab rejects calls to quit over Afghan interpreters
item.description: The foreign secretary is under fire for not personally asking for help to evacuate interpreters.

item.title: Kabul evacuation: No planes leaving empty says UK defence secretary
item.description: Defence Secretary Ben Wallace says "every hour counts", with up to 10 flights leaving every day.

item.title: Afghan interpreter who worked for UK begs PM for help
item.description: Ahmed, who fears Taliban reprisals, is desperate for him and his family to be evacuated from Kabul.

item.title: MPs on all sides accuse Boris Johnson of Afghanistan failures
item.description: The PM says the UK achieved its goals - but MPs accuse him of failing Afghans and British veterans.

item.title: Boris Johnson feels MPs' anger during Afghanistan debate
item.description: After a year of flat debates, a full Commons proved harder for the PM to navigate, writes Jessica Parker.

item.title: Labour Party: Strike threat over potential job cuts
item.description: Two unions representing party workers will ask their members if they will take action if cuts are enforced.

item.title: Tom Tugendhat on UK and Afghanistan: Anger, grief, rage
item.description: Tory MP Tom Tugendhat speaks of the anger, grief and rage of veterans at the "abandonment" of Afghanistan.

item.title: Covid: Most Conservative MPs ditch masks as Commons returns
item.description: Mask wearing appears to divide along party lines, during a packed debate on Afghanistan.

item.title: Austin Mitchell: Former Great Grimsby MP dies aged 86
item.description: Labour leader Keir Starmer leads tributes, saying Mr Mitchell served "with remarkable commitment".

item.title: I don't believe Taliban pledge on women's rights, Priti Patel says
item.description: The bulk of Afghans resettled in the UK will be persecuted minorities, the home secretary says.

item.title: Some Scots Covid powers 'could be made permanent'
item.description: Scottish ministers say some changes made during the pandemic had a "demonstrable benefit" to the public.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: Chaos at Kabul airport amid scramble to evacuate
item.description: Western countries are racing to evacuate their citizens and Afghans following the Taliban takeover.

item.title: Scottish public spending deficit doubles to £36bn
item.description: Spending on public services rose to almost £100bn as revenue fell due to the Covid pandemic.

item.title: Gurkha back at Downing Street hunger strike after being taken ill
item.description: Former Gurkha soldier Dhan Gurung returns to a protest over pensions after a health scare.

item.title: Plaid Cymru: Ex-leader no longer friends with successor
item.description: Leanne Wood says Adam Price made "a bad judgement call" in the timing of his leadership challenge.

item.title: Price rises cool amid clothes and shoe discounting
item.description: The UK inflation rate fell by more than expected to 2% in July, down from 2.5% the previous month.

item.title: Peterborough: Speeding MP off roads after asking for a ban
item.description: Conservative Paul Bristow wrote that he wanted to avoid "hypocrisy" after speeding on the A1.

item.title: US left too quickly, says Afghanistan bank governor
item.description: Afghanistan central bank governor, Ajmal Ahmady, tells the BBC he thinks country's economic situation will deteriorate.

item.title: Dawn Butler: Man sentenced for sending MP offensive message
item.description: The 70-year-old man admitted sending the message to Labour MP Dawn Butler in June.

item.title: Hydrogen power offers jobs boost, says government
item.description: Kick-starting a hydrogen industry could attract billions in investment, the UK government says.

item.title: New police CCTV use rules criticised as bare bones
item.description: However, the guidelines empowered police and maintained public trust, the Home Office says.

item.title: UK job vacancies at record high as wages pick up
item.description: Job vacancies hit 953,000 amid signs the country's labour market is rebounding "robustly".

item.title: Afghanistan: UK's Kabul evacuation operating at full pace - commander
item.description: The changing political situation means "we can't afford to pause and wait", Vice Adm Sir Ben Key says.

item.title: Geronimo the alpaca gets temporary reprieve as hearing is adjourned
item.description: A High Court hearing for a temporary injunction to halt his death is adjourned for 24 hours.

item.title: Afghanistan: Another 200 UK troops sent to Kabul evacuation
item.description: Around 700 troops were already in the Afghan capital to help UK citizens and others leave.

item.title: UK minister 'eager' for Cambo oil field talks
item.description: The UK's Scotland Office minister David Duguid says he wants to learn more about development of the site off Shetland.

item.title: UK scholarships for Afghan students paused
item.description: The government says the situation in Afghanistan means the British Embassy in Kabul cannot finalise plans.

item.title: Olympics and Paralympics: GB athletes to get more government funds in run-up to Paris Games in 2024
item.description: The government will increase its funding of Great Britain's Olympians and Paralympians by £23.4m annually to £77.4m a year to aid preparation for the Paris Games in 2024.

item.title: Council policies 'inconsistent' with climate goals
item.description: A third of English councils support policies that could increase emissions, BBC research suggests.

item.title: David Skelton: Is a new form of snobbery reshaping British politics?
item.description: The working classes are looked down upon for very different reasons than in the past, argues a new book.

item.title: Covid: Self-isolation ends for double-jabbed and under-18s
item.description: Rules change in England and Northern Ireland for contacts of people who test positive for Covid.

item.title: Afghanistan: UK has abandoned Afghan people, says senior MP
item.description: Tory MP Tom Tugendhat says the troop withdrawal is the biggest foreign policy disaster since Suez.

item.title: New powers sought to stop illegal ticket resales
item.description: The UK's competition watchdog is calling for stronger laws to act quickly against touts.

item.title: Plymouth shooting: Starmer asks why gunman had licence
item.description: The police watchdog is investigating the decision to give back Jake Davison's shotgun and certificate.

item.title: Afghanistan: Boris Johnson defends UK's role amid evacuation
item.description: Boris Johnson says there is "no military solution" to the situation as the Taliban advances.

item.title: Covid: Carrie Johnson urges pregnant women to get vaccinated
item.description: The PM's wife, who is expecting a baby, says she is "feeling great" after having her second vaccine.

item.title: Sturgeon urges UK government to reassess Cambo oil field plan
item.description: The first minister says proposals should be re-examined due to the severity of the climate emergency.

item.title: Covid: Record your cough to help improve detection, says government
item.description: The government wants people to send in samples of themselves breathing, coughing and reading aloud.

item.title: Starmer rejects McCluskey's claim Labour could be finished under his leadership
item.description: The Unite boss warns Labour could "go under" if Sir Keir Starmer remains leader, in a new autobiography.

item.title: Electric cars: Do ministers put their motor where their mouth is?
item.description: Politicians are keen for us to live greener lives, but how many have taken the electric car plunge?

item.title: Marble Arch Mound: Deputy leader resigns amid spiralling costs
item.description: Westminster Council's Melvyn Caplan steps down after total costs nearly doubled to £6m.

item.title: Afghanistan: Ex-Tory ministers attack Biden over troops pullout
item.description: Tory politicians say it is not too late for UK troops to stay - but the government rules it out.

item.title: UK economy rebounds as Covid restrictions ease
item.description: Retail, restaurants and hotels show strong growth between April and June but data misses forecasts.

item.title: Climate: WWF warns UK spending is lagging behind targets
item.description: The conservation group WWF says the UK government must keep its promises on climate change.

item.title: UK deportation flight to Jamaica leaves with dozens reprieved
item.description: A plane to Jamaica chartered by the Home Office was carrying just seven passengers, lawyers say.

item.title: David Cameron in row over promoting genetics firm Illumina
item.description: Mr Cameron encouraged Matt Hancock to speak at a conference co-hosted by Illumina before it won a government contract.

item.title: Harman: Women must be involved in Afghan discussions
item.description: A former acting Labour leader calls for women to be heard, rather than Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab.

item.title: Are you going to resign, Mr Raab?
item.description: The foreign secretary gives a one-word answer when asked about his future.

item.title: Ben Wallace: 'Every hour counts' of Kabul evacuation
item.description: The UK defence secretary spoke to BBC Breakfast about the evacuation of people from Kabul airport.

item.title: 'Where were we in their hour of need?': MPs debate the Afghanistan crisis
item.description: MPs, including Afghanistan veterans, were discussing the unfolding crisis in an emergency debate.

item.title: Afghanistan: Theresa May on politicians withdrawing UK troops
item.description: Ex-PM Theresa May says it is “incomprehensible and worrying” the UK could not work with other nations to “sustain” an Afghan government.

item.title: Biden's speech on Afghanistan fact-checked
item.description: How consistent was President Biden's speech with his previous statements on Afghanistan?

item.title: Afghanistan: How many asylum seekers has the UK taken in?
item.description: The UK government says it will resettle up to 20,000 Afghan refugees, but warns it will "take time".

item.title: Could Scots be guaranteed a minimum income?
item.description: The government is to start work on plans for an income guarantee scheme aimed at wiping out poverty in Scotland.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's the impact of Taliban's return on international order?
item.description: What is the diplomatic fallout and how allies and rivals are looking at the US following the Taliban takeover?

item.title: COP26: How serious is the government about climate conference?
item.description: With less than 90 days to go to Glasgow climate summit, there is uncertainty surrounding the event.

item.title: Ben Elliot: Conservative Party money man with A-list connections
item.description: Tory fundraiser and co-chairman Ben Elliot is at the centre of controversy over an elite donors club.

item.title: Berlin embassy arrest: A case of old-school spying?
item.description: Why nothing in the case of the arrest of a man at the British Embassy in Berlin should surprise us.

item.title: Boris Johnson: Why mining gaffe will linger after Scottish visit
item.description: Boris Johnson put his foot in it by joking that Margaret Thatcher gave the UK a "big early start" in the shift away from coal.

item.title: Riots 10 years on: The five summer nights when London burned
item.description: In August 2011 a man was shot dead by police in London, triggering the worst civil unrest in decades.

item.title: Indyref2: Why has the campaign for another vote gone quiet?
item.description: Boris Johnson visits Scotland with no sign an independence referendum will be soon, writes Nick Eardley.

item.title: Covid-19: Behind-the-scenes battles over amber watchlist
item.description: Cabinet divisions over international travel rules spilled out into the open this week, writes Adam Fleming.

item.title: Tragedy became Sliding Doors moment for politician
item.description: Julie James's life changed overnight when the father of her first child was killed in a car crash.

item.title: Guli Francis-Dehqani: The bishop tackling England's housing crisis
item.description: The Church of England owns a lot of land - Guli Francis-Dehqani wants to use it for the common good.
